definition: Radioactive metallic elements with atomic numbers 89-103, including uranium and transuranics

positive_examples: The uranium fuel rods were carefully handled due to their radioactive properties
Plutonium-239 is used in nuclear weapons and reactor fuel
Thorium reactors offer a safer alternative to conventional nuclear power
Americium-241 is commonly found in household smoke detectors
The neptunium isotope was produced artificially in the particle accelerator
Curium samples require special containment due to their intense radioactivity
negative_examples: The radon gas accumulated in the basement over time
Cesium-137 contamination spread after the nuclear accident
The technetium isotope is widely used in medical imaging
Polonium poisoning was suspected in the assassination case
Radium paint made the watch dials glow in the dark
The tritium exit signs provided emergency lighting
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: Lanthanides, TransitionMetals, AlkaliMetals, NobleGases, Halogens

opposite_reasoning: NobleGas provides the strongest semantic opposition within the same ontological category (chemical elements). The contrast between highly reactive/radioactive metals and inert/stable non-metals maximizes chemical distance while maintaining taxonomic coherence. This creates a clean Fisher-LDA axis: reactive-radioactive-metallic ↔ inert-stable-nonmetallic. Noble gases likely exist in both WordNet and SUMO ontologies, making this practical for implementation.
